results.title: In limbo
results.creator_credit: Iris Pictures, SBS Independent, Jessica Douglas-Henry and Dai Le
results.brief_description: In limbo follows the story of an Australian -Vietnamese lawyer who is determined to see 2000 Vietnamese boat people stranded in the Philippines regain the lives, identities and homes. Hoi Trinh as been fighting for the rights of these people for more than five years. It’s a mammoth undertaking involving political lobbying and complex negotiations with immigration departments in Australia, the United States, Europe, Japan and the Philippines. This film sees Hoi battle the Australian Immigration Department bureaucracy as he tries to resettle 50 refugee familles in Australia. A moving and poignant documentary, this work provides an insight into the immigration debate through one man’s struggle.

results.title: In life's cycle
results.brief_description: A “temperance melodrama” about the effects of alcohol within a relationship when a young farm girl seeking to escape her drab life runs away with a city slicker who has a propensity for drinking and turning violent. Cast includes Stephanie Longfellow, Charles West, George Nichols, Linda Arvidson, Adele DeGarde. Silent film with English intertitles.

results.title: In heaven there is no beer
results.creator_credit: Flower Films, Les Blank and Maureen Gosling
results.brief_description: This film visits a number of intensive polka sessions (one of them an 11-day marathon) and observes the wildly enthusiastic participants. The film also examines the dancers’ Polish patriotism and their polka regalia, concluding that they may find a close and authentic sense of community through this form of folk art.

results.title: In harbour
results.creator_credit: Australian National Film Board, Eric Thompson and Joan Boundy
results.brief_description: Shows the work of the many people who are engaged in working on Sydney Harbour - the fishermen who gain their livelihood from its waters, those who maintain its laws and ensure its cleanliness, those who maintain its equipment and preserve its many miles of wharves and those who dredge its bed and attend to its buoys. They keep the harbour for the ships from many lands to use, but themselves never go “outside”.

results.title: In good company
results.brief_description: A recruiting film made to encourage young men to join the Army as officers. Shows the Officers Training School at Portsea in Victoria, the Royal Military College at Duntroon in Canberra and gives an insight into the lifestyle and career opportunities offered by the Army to any young man who wishes both to further his education at a tertiary level as well as seek a challenging and rewarding career as an officer in the Australian Army.

results.title: In good company
results.creator_credit: Movietonenews, Frank Killian and Syd Wood
results.brief_description: Role and training in Australian Citizen Military Forces of part-time soldiers important in Australia’s defence; attendance at weekly parades, weekend bivouacs and annual camps where modern weapons, mock-up battles are used to provide realistic battle and trade experience. Army medical nurses, Women’s Royal Australian Army Corps, and Commandos learn bandaging, marching and boat-handling respectively as they train. Commentator: Kevin Golsby.

results.title: In fear of every dawn [Magnetic soundtrack]
results.brief_description: Western propaganda presenting life on the Eastern side of the ‘Berlin Wall’. Filmed from the Western side of the border, the film records activities on the Eastern side and provides an anti-communist interpretation and commentary. Shows locals carrying out daily activities; armed guards patrolling the border; watch-towers and concealed observation areas; propaganda billboards; ‘indoctrinated’ youths recruited as guards and frontier police; the ‘forcible’ removal of families from their ancestral homes into detention centres; and endless footage of barbed wire and uniformed personnel.

results.title: In dreams
results.creator_credit: NBCUniversal, Stephen Woolley and Neil Jordan
results.brief_description: Claire (Annette Bening), a children’s book illustrator, lives in a large, rustic New England home in idyllic Massachusetts with her daughter, Rebecca, and husband, Paul (Aidan Quinn), an airline-pilot. At the same time a serial killer threatens the safety of young girls in the community, Claire begins experiencing horrible and nightmarish dreams. The fabric of her dreams not only resembles her illustration work but also the terrible events occurring in the local community. In a truly unnerving twist, it’s revealed that Claire’s unconscious is possessed by the killer. As reality and the dream world collapse, tragedy, violence and confusion ensues. Confined to a mental institution and treated by the ineffectual Doctor Silverman (Stephen Rea), Claire - under the influence of Vivian Thompson (Robert Downey Jr.) - escapes and faces her maligned alterego head on. In a splendid closing montage of water imagery, Claire ultimately finds harmony, peace and tranquillity. By acclaimed director Neil Jordan, “In Dreams” is a dark and unnerving film that gives full and rich exploration to the theme of the unconscious as a pool of mixed desires and impulses. Also features excellent cinematography by Darius Khondji.

results.title: In conversation with Bill Viola: Melbourne International Arts Festival 2010
results.brief_description:
In October 2010, renowned American artist Bill Viola travelled to Melbourne to install two exhibitions of his work : ‘The Raft’ at ACMI and ‘Fire Woman and Tristan’s Ascension’ at St Carthage’s Catholic Church in Parkville. Presented by ACMI along with Melbourne International Arts Festival and Kaldor Public Art Projects, these two exhibitions gave Melbourne audiences a unique chance to experience the work of one of the world’s more influential and important artists.

Viola has been instrumental in the establishment of video as a vital form of contemporary art. For over 40 years he has created videotapes, architectural video installations, sound environments, electronic music performances, flat panel video pieces and works for television broadcast. His video installations – total environments that envelop the viewer in image and sound – employ state-of-the-art technologies and are distinguished by their precision and direct simplicity.

In this film Bill Viola is in conversation with Rachel Kohn, Producer and Presenter of ‘The Spirit of things’ and ‘The Ark’ on Radio National.
